symptoms: Dark brown to black concentric spots on older leaves
Yellowing and withering of affected leaves
Spots may enlarge and form target-like patterns

cultural_controls: Rotate crops (avoid planting potatoes or tomatoes in the same field every year)
Ensure proper plant spacing for air flow

organic_remedies.name: Neem oil spray
organic_remedies.application: Spray on affected leaves every 5–7 days early in the morning

organic_remedies.name: Baking soda spray
organic_remedies.application: Spray weekly to prevent fungal spread

organic_remedies.name: Cow dung slurry
organic_remedies.application: Ferment cow dung with water for 3 days, filter, and spray; helps as a microbial deterrent

chemical_controls.name: Mancozeb 75% WP
chemical_controls.note: Apply every 7–10 days during early symptoms

chemical_controls.name: Chlorothalonil 75% WP
chemical_controls.note: Alternate with other fungicides to avoid resistance

locally_available_solutions: Neem oil (available in agri stores and online platforms)
Baking soda and soap (general household items)
Cow dung (locally available from cattle owners)
Mancozeb and Chlorothalonil (sold at local Krishi Kendras)
precaution: Always test any spray on a small part of the plant before full application. Use PPE when spraying chemicals.
summary: Fungal disease in tomatoes and potatoes. Causes dark leaf spots with concentric rings. Needs fungicide & rotation.
